description.narrative: Geneva Call is a neutral and impartial organisation dedicated to promoting respect by armed non-state actors (ANSAs) for international humanitarian norms in armed conflict and other situations of violence, in particular those related to the protection of civilians. The overall intended outcome of Geneva Call's engagements with ANSAs is improved respect for humanitarian norms in armed conflict, with the ultimate goal of a better protection for civilian populations.

Core support to Geneva Call, a neutral and impartial NGO dedicated to promoting respect by armed non-State actors for international humanitarian law (IHL). In adddition to strengthening IHL in general, GC focuses on the ban on the use of anti-personnel mines, protecting children in armed conflict (especially preventing the recruitment of children in hostilities) as well as the prohibition against sexual violence in conflict.

Geneva Call är en internationell NGO som är specialiserad på dialog med icke-statliga väpnade aktörer (Armed Non-State Actors - ANSAs) med målet att öka deras respekt för internationella normer och principer, särskilt vad gäller skydd av civila i väpnad konflikt. Organisationens viktigaste verktyg för engagemang med ANSAs är så kallade Deeds of Commitment, som möjliggör för dessa grupper att formellt ansluta sig till specifika humanitära normer, inklusive: Totalförbud mot truppminor och att samarbeta i minröjning; Skydd av barn från konsekvenserna av väpnad konflikt, och; Förbud mot sexuellt våld i väpnad konflikt och att undanröja könsdiskriminering. Utöver dessa tre huvudprinciper utbildar Geneva Call ickestatliga väpnade aktörer i internationell humanitär rätt i bredare termer.
I organisationens nuvarande strategiska plan för perioden 2017-2019 ingår också att stärka engagemanget kring ett antal ytterligare normer och principer, som till exempel skydd från tvångsförflyttningar och skydd av skolor och universitet från att användas som militära mål och medel.
Sida har gett kärnstöd till Geneva Call sedan 2008. Det första stödet 2008-2010 var på totalt 7,5 MSEK och finansierades genom anslaget för humanitära insatser och konflikthantering. Kärnstödet förnyades med 7,5 SEK för perioden 2011-2013 inom anlaget för globala insatser. 2014 förnyades kärnstödet till Geneva Call med 18 miljoner kr för perioden 2014-2016, inom Resultatstrategin för globala insatser för mänsklig säkerhet 2014-2017. Samarbetet bedöms vara strategiskt och effektivt. Geneva Call har ett unikt mandat och fyller en viktigt funktion för skydd av civila i väpnade konflikter. Organisationen har genomfört planerade aktiviteter på ett effektivt sätt och har nått uppsatta mål och resultat i mycket osäkra och svårarbetade miljöer. Sida gör bedömningen att stödet är fortsatt relevant i relation till Resultatstrategin för globala insatser för mänsklig säkerhet (2014-2017).

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: During the contribution period Geneva Call’s operations has showed progress in the conflict contexts where they are active. Geneva Call has engaged Armed Non-State Actors (ANSAs) in 25 countries, of which 18 were engaged for the first time. The engagement has lead to ANSAs taking actions to improve their respect for humanitarian norms. These actions not only included changing their policies or signing Deeds of Commitment with Geneva Call, but also taking concrete measures such as releasing children from their ranks, opening up new areas to humanitarian mine action, destroying stockpiles of anti-personnel mines, disseminating internal rules to their soldiers and training them to abide by humanitarian norms in the conduct of hostilities. Most armed conflicts today are non-international and involve ANSAs, either fighting government forces or other ANSAs. Many violations of International Humanitarian Law (IHL) are committed by ANSAs. Yet, there is little systematic engagement with them to enhance the respect for international norms. The state-centric nature of the international law poses further challenges as it is predominantly focused on states and ANSAs cannot become parties to relevant international treaties. During the contribution period Geneva Call initiated a humanitarian dialogue on the key rules of IHL with a number of ANSAs in countries such as DRC, Libya, Mali, South Sudan, Syria, Afghanistan, Ukraine, Yemen and Iraq. The interaction takes place in different levels, such as awareness raising, increase of knowledge on IHL and humanitarian norms, policy change, etc. Sexual violence and rape in particular, are pervasive in many armed conflicts. Activities promoting gender equality and condemning sexual violence were undertaken in different contexts. ANSAs engaged with Geneva Call participated in awareness-raising and training sessions on gender issues and strengthened their capacities and internal rules and regulations, namely in Myanmar, Colombia, the DRC, Iran, Lebanon, the Philippines, Sudan, Syria, and Turkey. In 2018 a humanitarian dialogue on gender was initiated with 2 additional ANSAs in Syria. Specific attention was also paid to the inclusion of women in decision-making and especially in the peacebuilding process. Women’s participation and representation in peace talks has been an important element addressed and promoted by the operations’ teams in different contexts such as: Colombia, Yemen, Lebanon, Ukraine, etc. In the recent years, it has become increasingly common for medical personnel and facilities to come under attack. With the support of legal experts and practitioners, Geneva Call has developed a Deed of Commitment on protecting health care in armed conflict. This tool help engage ANSAs to: i) ensure access for affected populations to essential health care facilities, goods and services; and ii) facilitate the provision of health care by impartial humanitarian organisations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
